questions.a: Let ∅ != A ⊆ R. Suppose that A is bounded from above. Then there exists a unique s s.t. s is a least upper bound of A

questions.q: The epsilon prop of the least upper bound
questions.a: Let ∅ != A ⊆ R. Suppose that A is bounded from above and let s be an upper bound of A. Then s = sup(A) iff ∀ ε > 0 ∃ a in A s.t. a > s - ε
∀ M in R ∃ n in N s.t. n > M
∀ ε > 0 ∃ n in N s.t. 1/n < ε
Let ∅ != A ⊆ Z. Suppose that A is bounded from above. Then A has a maximal value.
R \ Q is dense in R
Let x0 and let f be a function that is defined on a deleted neighborhood of x0. Let L1, L2 and suppose that L1, L2 are two limits of f at x0. Then L1 = L2.

Let x0 and let f,g be two functions defined on a deleted neighborhood of x0. Let L1, L2 and suppose that L1 = lim from x->x0 f(x) and that L2 = lim from x->x0 g(x). Suppose also that f(x) <= g(x) for every x in that deleted neighborhood. Then L1 <= L2

Let x0 and let f,g,h be three functions that are defined on a deleted neighborhood of x0. Let L and suppose that:
1. h(x) <= f(x) <= g(x) for every x in that deleted neighborhood
2. L = lim from x -> x0 h(x) = lim from x -> x0 g(x)

Then lim from x -> x0 f(x) = L

Let a,b s.t. a < b and let f be a function that is defined at least on [a,b]. Suppose that f is continuous on [a,b]. Suppose also that f(a) * f(b) < 0. Then there exists a point a < c < b s.t. f(c) = 0
